items.synopsis: A combination of old-fashioned espionage and high-tech surveillance was meant to keep Israelis safe. But when Hamas smashed through the fence, all the systems seemed to fail.

title.children: Paragliders, kidnappings and rockets: How did Hamas pull off such an audacious attack?

image.altText: Fire and smoke rise following an Israeli airstrike, in Gaza City.

items.synopsis: As the death toll from Hamas attacks on Israel and counterstrikes in Gaza climbs, Israel officially declares war and vows to attack Hamas targets.

title.children: Hundreds of bodies recovered from music festival as Israel formally declares war over Hamas attack

image.altText: A woman in a 'DISRUPT BURRUP HUB' T-shirt stands in the street with her arms raised

items.synopsis: The battle over the climate is escalating, and nowhere more than in Western Australia, where a new generation of protesters is prepared to break the law to make their point.

title.children: Climate protesters targeted an oil and gas CEO at her home. This is the inside story of what happened

image.altText: A two-image compilation of three women standing together and laughing, with a young woman hugging a humanoid puppet.

items.synopsis: A cruel and incurable disease took former TV personality Fiona MacDonald's voice, and her trademark quick wit and banter with it. But she's not staying silent.

title.children: 'There is no treatment, no cure': Why Fiona MacDonald is making every second count

image.altText: A man smiles and gestures for the camera.

items.synopsis: Israel says it is at war as its soldiers battle Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel and launch air strikes on Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: 'A machine gun started going off': Australian describes fleeing music festival near Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We heard earlier that the US doesn't have any evidence Iran was involved in the Hamas attack, but that is their concern. Reuters has just dropped an update from Tehran. Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said during a cabinet meeting the attack on Israel was "a manifestation of resistance and standing against the fake Zionist regime". "The Palestinian people, the Palestinian soldiers, all Palestinian groups, and the Islamic Ummah really should be congratulated for this victory." President Raisi has referred to "Palestinian people", but it's important to note the difference between the soldiers of Hamas and the civilian population. The attack on Israel was a Hamas operation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iran weighs in

children.content: We heard earlier that the US doesn't have any evidence Iran was involved in the Hamas attack, but that is their concern.
Reuters has just dropped an update from Tehran.
Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said during a cabinet meeting the attack on Israel was "a manifestation of resistance and standing against the fake Zionist regime".
"The Palestinian people, the Palestinian soldiers, all Palestinian groups, and the Islamic Ummah really should be congratulated for this victory."
President Raisi has referred to "Palestinian people", but it's important to note the difference between the soldiers of Hamas and the civilian population. The attack on Israel was a Hamas operation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Ashleigh Barraclough Australian man Daniel Moritz was at the music festival near Gaza which came under attack by Hamas militants. So far, 260 bodies have been recovered. Mr Moritz said he and some friends were enjoying the festival when they were caught off guard. "Around 6am, we noticed bombings above our head — no sirens, nothing went off," he told ABC Radio Melbourne. "Totally surprised, totally unaware and unprotected." He and his five friends decided to flee in their car straight away. "We just came to the decision, our friends, to get out of there, leave our stuff, leave our tents — everything," he said. "Luckily, we parked really close to the entrance. We found a hole in the fence so we managed to get out faster. "We started to head north, we thought we were protected, and suddenly a machine gun started going off, just shooting at us full force. "We hear the whistles of the bullets flying over our heads, we're ducking down in the car." He said he and his friends managed to escape uninjured, and he's now back home in northern Israel. "What's going on right now in the country is chaos," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Bullets flying over our head': Australian man describes attack at music festival near Gaza

children.content: Daniel Moritz, left, was at the music festival when it came under attack.
(Supplied)
Reporting by
Ashleigh Barraclough
Australian man
Daniel Moritz
was at the music festival near Gaza which came under attack by Hamas militants.
So far, 260 bodies have been recovered.
Mr Moritz said he and some friends were enjoying the festival when they were caught off guard.
"Around 6am, we noticed bombings above our head — no sirens, nothing went off," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.
"Totally surprised, totally unaware and unprotected."
He and his five friends decided to flee in their car straight away.
"We just came to the decision, our friends, to get out of there, leave our stuff, leave our tents — everything," he said.
"Luckily, we parked really close to the entrance. We found a hole in the fence so we managed to get out faster.
"We started to head north, we thought we were protected, and suddenly a machine gun started going off, just shooting at us full force.
"We hear the whistles of the bullets flying over our heads, we're ducking down in the car."
He said he and his friends managed to escape uninjured, and he's now back home in northern Israel.
"What's going on right now in the country is chaos," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier this morning a meeting of the full UN Security Council began in New York. We've been told it is unlikely to issue a statement, but we will bring you as many updates as we are able to obtain. Ahead of the meeting, we heard from both the Israeli and the Palestinian ambassadors to the UN. Israeli UN ambassador Gilad Erdan said: "These are war crimes, blatant documented war crimes. The era of reasoning with these savages is over. Now is the time to obliterate Hamas terror infrastructure, to completely erase it, so that such horrors are never committed again." Palestinian UN ambassador Riyad Mansour said: "Israel keeps saying: The blockade and repeated assaults on Gaza are to destroy Hamas military capabilities and ensure security. ... Its blockade and assaults accomplished neither. When Israel now tries to justify yet another assault by the same faulty premise, no one should say or do anything to encourage it down this path."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The UN Security Council has been meeting in New York

children.content: Israel’s Ambassador to the United Nations Gilad Erdan speaks during a meeting of the United Nations Security Council
(Reuters: Mike Segar)
Earlier this morning a meeting of the full UN Security Council began in New York. We've been told it is unlikely to issue a statement, but we will bring you as many updates as we are able to obtain.
Ahead of the meeting, we heard from both the Israeli and the Palestinian ambassadors to the UN.
Israeli UN ambassador Gilad Erdan said:

"These are war crimes, blatant documented war crimes. The era of reasoning with these savages is over. Now is the time to obliterate Hamas terror infrastructure, to completely erase it, so that such horrors are never committed again."
Palestinian UN ambassador Riyad Mansour said:

"Israel keeps saying: The blockade and repeated assaults on Gaza are to destroy Hamas military capabilities and ensure security. ... Its blockade and assaults accomplished neither. When Israel now tries to justify yet another assault by the same faulty premise, no one should say or do anything to encourage it down this path."

items.synopsis: The ASX is set to open higher at the beginning of trade on Monday after strong jobs data and tech stocks rallied on Wall Street on Friday, while oil prices are keenly in focus in response to Hamas's attack on Israel. Follow live.

title.children: Oil prices in focus after Hamas attack, ASX to rise after stronger jobs data and tech stocks rally on Wall Street

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has opened higher at the beginning of trade on Monday morning, up 0.4% to 6,982 points as of 10:35am AEDT. (If you want more up-to-date figures, jump to the top of the blog and expand the pinned post for live market updates for the major ASX indices.) Energy stocks are mostly responsible for the higher opening, with the sector up 2.1%. Th e basic materials sector is also up 1.3%, while academic and educational services picked up 0.9%. Utilities (+0.5%), consumer cyclicals (+0.4%) and real estate (+0.2%) round out the early gains for the sectors. Consumer non-cyclicals have had the biggest drop so far (-0.6%), followed by industrials (-0.1%). The technology, healthcare and financials sectors are all flat. The best performers so far: De Grey Mining +8.5% Bellevue Gold +6.9% Evolution Mining +5.7% Capricorn Metals +5.5% Northern Star Resources +5.4% And the worst performers so far: Weebit Nano -10.9% Magellan Financial -2.7% Qantas -1.7% Paladin Energy -1.5% Life360 -1.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boost in energy stocks sends ASX higher at beginning of trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Parent company of IGA, Metcash, says the CEO of its liquor branch, Chris Baddock, has retired from the role for health reasons. In a short statement uploaded to the ASX earlier this morning, Metcash says John Barakat will take over the role in the interim while the company searches for a successor. Metcash CEO Doug Jones thanked Mr Baddock for his "significant contribution" in growing the company's liquor pillar, and said he would take up a part-time advisory role with Metcash after a four-month break to assist with the growth of the liquor division.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Metcash Liquor CEO retires from role for health reasons

children.content: Parent company of IGA, Metcash, says the CEO of its liquor branch, Chris Baddock, has retired from the role for health reasons.
In a short statement uploaded to the ASX earlier this morning, Metcash says John Barakat will take over the role in the interim while the company searches for a successor.

Metcash CEO Doug Jones thanked Mr Baddock for his "significant contribution" in growing the company's liquor pillar, and said he would take up a part-time advisory role with Metcash after a four-month break to assist with the growth of the liquor division.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With Peter Costello stepping down from the Future Fund next February, Treasurer Jim Chalmers is now tasked with appointing a new chair. Mr Chalmers has thanked Mr Costello for his "significant contribution" with the fund, and a formal merit-based recruitment process will get underway to find a replacement chair. You can hear more from our senior business correspondent Peter Ryan below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Merit-based' recruitment process underway for Future Fund chair replacement

title.children: AFL trade period gets underway as off-season drama ramps up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Sydney will be one of the busiest clubs over the next two weeks as they look to put the finishing touches on a squad they believe can compete for a flag. As mentioned before, James Jordon and Joel Hamling have already joined as free agents, so there has been no cost to the Swans there. But both Brodie Grundy and Taylor Adams are keen to head to the harbour city too, and those deals will need to be done via trades. The Swans currently have picks 11, 23, 31, 44 and 52. They will not want to use pick 11 in either of these deals, but both Melbourne and Collingwood will be eyeing off that pick 23. So is it 23 for Adams and 31 for Grundy? Vice versa? Or will some of those later picks needed be in to flesh things out? No doubt the Swans will get their men, but there could be some negotiating to get through first.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Taylor Adams, Brodie Grundy and the Swans' dilemma

children.content: (Getty Images)
Sydney will be one of the busiest clubs over the next two weeks as they look to put the finishing touches on a squad they believe can compete for a flag.

As mentioned before, James Jordon and Joel Hamling have already joined as free agents, so there has been no cost to the Swans there. But both Brodie Grundy and Taylor Adams are keen to head to the harbour city too, and those deals will need to be done via trades.
The Swans currently have picks
11, 23, 31, 44 and 52. They will not want to use pick 11 in either of these deals, but both Melbourne and Collingwood will be eyeing off that pick 23.

So is it 23 for Adams and 31 for Grundy? Vice versa? Or will some of those later picks needed be in to flesh things out? No doubt the Swans will get their men, but there could be some negotiating to get through first.

title.children: Is there really a 1 in 6 chance of human extinction this century?
